data.text: One thing I forgot, looks matters.There are so many blogs I visit that are ugly, have poor design, and are difficult to navigate. If your blog looks like a 2 year old designed it, then you can have the best writing possible, and it's going to be difficult to get regular visitors.
What they aren't mentioning is your angle. It may seem too ultra specific, but taking ultra specific and unique angles is what's going to make people come back to read you.

The fourth most important trait for reviewing films? Find an angle. It's easy to summarize and evaluate. That's not going to separate you. The angles and how you connect to something is what's going to. Read other reviewers reviewing the same films. What aren't they mentioning?

Third most important trait for reviewing films? Push your writing. Never be satisfied. Always reevaluate how you communicate. Question your word choices, your assumptions, your reasoning. Good rule of thumb is to review for a month, then evaluate those reviews. Rinse and repeat.

The second most important trait for reviewing films? Be able to admit when you got it wrong, negatively or positively. Films change us, and we change from films. Be willing to reevaluate your stances. If you hated a film, give it some time, see it again down the road.
